                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1413139919383_2020">
                    <p class="comment-content" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1413139919383_2043">
                    Safe removal of the protective gear is the most challenging part of the whole process when one deals with extreme hazards like Ebola. One needs to develop a culture of appreciation of the procedure which comes with repeating it hundreds of times - that's why the miltary from ABC detachments almost never had safety incidents. My suggestion would be for anyone who is to be assigned to the Ebola treatment to practice de-gowning (supervised) at least 20 times. As this requires at least 8-10 hrs of [paid] time, I guess the hospital saved on the training - now they will spend a million caring for the poor nurse.
                    </p>

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1413139919383_2086">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Why people should want to help! In the 1980's I had just begun my nursing career and AIDS/HIV epidemic was entering the states. I worked on the oncology unit and this is where patients affected with HIV were sent. I wasn't 20 years old yet. I remember other hospital staff refusing to gown up to take care of this patient, but I volunteered too! He was only 25 years old and not even his own family would come see him because they were worried that they could be affected! I would go visit him after my shift and just sit in his room with him visiting about his life and how scared he was since even the hospital staff didn't spend anymore time in his room than needed. He finally asked me one day why was I not fearful of getting HIV from him. I said I made the choice to take care of people no matter what the outcome may be. The reason I spent so much time with him was I realized... What if this was one of my family members or friends? Would I want the people I entrusted to care for them to turn their back out of fear? The answer for me was NO! I can't and will not turn my back in someone else's time of need if I can help them. In less than 9 months I watched this young man wither up and looked as if he was in his 70's before he died. But in my heart he knew he wasn't alone, I made sure of that. Although many of you are worried about the what if's .... You need to live for today. I also did not mind owning up to go see him anytime because he wasn't able to leave that room but I was. So please think about not only the illness but also the isolation these EBOLA patients are going through now. If it was you or your family member could you honestly walk away!
                    </p>

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    ""PRESIDENT EBOLA: In 2010 Obama Administration Scrapped CDC Quarantine Regulations Aimed At Ebola""<br>
 by Wochit  0:50 mins 5,100 views<br>
<br>
In October 2014, the first patient on American soil infected with the Ebola virus sits in isolation in a Texas hospital, prompting calls for travel restrictions between the United States and Ebola-stricken countries. Meanwhile, four years ago, the administration of President Barack Obama moved with virtually no fanfare to abandon a comprehensive set of regulations which the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) had called essential to preventing international travelers from spreading deadly diseases inside the United States. The CDC had proposed the regulations in 2005 under the administration of George W. Bush, reported USA Today in 2010. The original impetus for the regulations was fear that avian flu would spread unchecked.<br>
<br>
<br>
Wochit
                    </p>

            <div class="container">
                <div class="nickname">
                        <span tabindex="0" class="int profile-link" data-guid="5TYJAMRIQXIKTML2CM7A22JHFU">noneya</span>
                    <span class="comment-timestamp">3 hours ago</span>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="down-vote-box" class="int vote-box down">
                        <span class="count">1</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbDown Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-down"></i>
                    </div>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="up-vote-box" class="int vote-box up">
                        <span class="count">11</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbUp Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-up"></i>
                    </div>

                </div>
                <div class="text-container comments-truncate">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    How you need to deal with Ebola/Marburg. It's not a new thing, maybe to you it is.<br>
BSL-4 builds upon the containment requirements of BSL-3 and is the highest level of <br>
biological safety. There are a small number of BSL-4 labs in the United States and around the world. The microbes in a BSL-4 lab are dangerous and exotic, posing a high risk of aerosol-transmitted infections. Infections caused by these microbes are frequently fatal and without treatment or vaccines. Two examples of microbes worked with in a BSL-4 laboratory include Ebola and Marburg viruses.<br>
<br>
In addition to BSL-3 considerations, BSL-4 laboratories have the following containment requirements:<br>
Laboratory practices<br>
    Change clothing before entering.<br>
    Shower upon exiting.<br>
    Decontaminate all materials before exiting.<br>
Safety equipment<br>
    All work with the microbe must be performed within an appropriate Class III BSC , or by wearing a full body, air-supplied, positive pressure A suit.<br>
Facility construction<br>
    The laboratory is in a separate building or in an isolated and restricted zone of the building.<br>
    The laboratory has dedicated supply and exhaust air, as well as vacuum lines and <br>
decontamination systems.
                    </p>
                    <div class="more-text-button">More</div>
                </div>

            <div class="container">
                <div class="nickname">
                        <span tabindex="0" class="int profile-link" data-guid="5TYJAMRIQXIKTML2CM7A22JHFU">noneya</span>
                    <span class="comment-timestamp">3 hours ago</span>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="down-vote-box" class="int vote-box down">
                        <span class="count">2</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbDown Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-down"></i>
                    </div>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="up-vote-box" class="int vote-box up">
                        <span class="count">45</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbUp Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-up"></i>
                    </div>

                </div>
                <div class="text-container comments-truncate">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Ebola survivor Nancy Writebol also doesn’t know how she got the virus:<br>
    I don’t know how I became infected and how I contracted it. There are some thoughts about how I might have gotten it. Nobody is really sure, least of all me. I never felt like I was unsafe and I never felt like I walked into a situation where I was being exposed. I was on the low-risk side of things. I never was in the crisis or the Ebola center. I was always on the outside. I made sure doctors and nurses were dressed properly before they went in, and I decontaminated them before they went out. We kept a close check on each other about whether people felt safe.<br>
    We had an employee who was doing the same job that I was doing. He got sick and I didn’t know he was sick. He didn’t tell anybody. He actually thought he had typhoid. The day that I started having symptoms, at least a fever, was the last day I saw him. He did have Ebola. He did not survive.<br>
    I never remember touching him, although it’s possible he could have picked up a sprayer to decontaminate someone, and I could have picked up the sprayer. Or we touched the same thing. I never touched him.
                    </p>

                    <button tabindex="0" class="comments-button-small flag Bxz-bb P-2" title="Report Abuse">
                        <i class="Icon C-w Fz-m"></i>
                    </button>
        </div>            <div class="img-container">
                <img src="http://l.yimg.com/dh/ap/social/profile/profile_b48.png" title="doitnow" width="48" height="48">            </div>
            <div class="container">
                <div class="nickname">
                        <span tabindex="0" class="int profile-link" data-guid="DWDNGK5V3SAS4PS5B5ECMZPN2Q">doitnow</span>
                    <span class="comment-timestamp">3 hours ago</span>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="down-vote-box" class="int vote-box down">
                        <span class="count">1</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbDown Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-down"></i>
                    </div>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="up-vote-box" class="int vote-box up">
                        <span class="count">4</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbUp Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-up"></i>
                    </div>

                </div>
                <div class="text-container comments-truncate">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    The research of Drs. Ron Fouchier and Yoshihiro Kawaoka looked at making bird flu evolve into a super flu spread by air and animals back in 2011. Previously, you mainly got H5n1 or H7N9 by being in close contact with infected birds. It was not person to person. They were able to achieve air borne status in H5N1 virus by genetically modifying it. They used Ferrets as the host and in 10 evolution, they did what mother nature would likely have taken maybe hundreds of years to do because they wanted to prove that if they can do it in the lab, mother nature can do it too, Of course you see the logic in that rational, right?<br>
 Not only that, they brought the mortality rate from 9.6% up to 75%. Then they fought to publish the results of how to get from point A to B, so that any bio grad student could replicate the experiment.  What if this process was used in Ebola? What if this was going on at the  level 3 bio-hazard lab in Sierra Leone? The Ebola virus previously was a slow evolving virus. It made changes at 1/10 the rate of the common cold. Now it has changed more than 300 times at last check, since this latest epidemic started. That is more or less 1 evolution per 100 persons infected. People are using proper procedure with far better equipment than they have in west Africa and yet they are still getting infected.  The methods in the past that kept it under control in Africa don't seem to be working, so clearly something is different, and that is if you don't fact in the lack of known host in west Africa. The cocktail of variety of Ebola strains and the seeming ease of transmission. an there is one more thing that is different in this Ebola. The index patient is suspected to have been a preschool child. All other index cases of Ebola in the past were men who were in areas with the known vectors.
                    </p>

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    “Don’t touch the walls!” a Western medical technician yelled out. “Totally infected.”<br>
Some Ebola patients still die at the hospital, perhaps four per day, in the tentlike temporary isolation ward at the back of the muddy grounds. But just as many, if not more, are dying in the city and neighboring villages, greatly increasing the risk of spreading the disease and <br>
undermining international efforts to halt the epidemic.“People don’t die here now,” said the deputy chief of the hospital’s burying team, Albert J. Mattia, exasperated after a long day of Ebola burials. “They are dying in the community, five, six a day.” Mr. Mattia was particularly disturbed that many of the bodies his team were putting in the ground had come from <br>
outside the hospital, thwarting attempts to isolate patients and prevent them from passing the disease to others.<br>
It's hard to catch Ebola/Marburg when it's in Africa, and you're in some other far away country, but when the infected are in your neighborhood, and at your local hospital/clinic, it's very easy to become infected.
                    </p>

        <div class="comment-container clearfix   ">

                    <button tabindex="0" class="comments-button-small flag Bxz-bb P-2" title="Report Abuse">

        </div>            <div class="img-container">
                <img src="http://l.yimg.com/dh/ap/social/profile/profile_b48.png" title="noneya" width="48" height="48">            </div>
            <div class="container">
                <div class="nickname">
                        <span tabindex="0" class="int profile-link" data-guid="5TYJAMRIQXIKTML2CM7A22JHFU">noneya</span>

                    <div tabindex="0" id="down-vote-box" class="int vote-box down">
                        <span class="count">2</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbDown Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-down"></i>

                    <div tabindex="0" id="up-vote-box" class="int vote-box up">
                        <span class="count">3</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbUp Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-up"></i>
                    </div>

                </div>
                <div class="text-container comments-truncate">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    From WHO<br>
Ebola is a severe, infectious often-fatal disease in humans and nonhuman primates (monkeys, gorillas, and chimpanzees) caused by infection with Ebola virus.  It is very infectious, kills in a short time BUT can be prevented.<br>
How is it spread?<br>
People can be exposed to Ebola virus from direct physical contact with body fluids like blood, saliva, stool, urine, sweat etc. of an infected person and soiled linen used by a patient.<br>
It can be spread through contact with objects, such as needles, that have been <br>
contaminated with infected secretions.
                    </p>

        <div class="comment-container clearfix   ">
        <div class="actions">
                    <button tabindex="0" class="comments-button-small flag Bxz-bb P-2" title="Report Abuse">
                        <i class="Icon C-w Fz-m"></i>
                    </button>
        </div>            <div class="img-container">
                <img src="http://l.yimg.com/dh/ap/social/profile/profile_b48.png" title="Lucy Fir" width="48" height="48">            </div>
            <div class="container">
                <div class="nickname">
                        <span tabindex="0" class="int profile-link" data-guid="SHNYUAVANZFY7IARLAZEUCULII">Lucy Fir</span>
                    <span class="comment-timestamp">2 hours ago</span>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="down-vote-box" class="int vote-box down">
                        <span class="count">3</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbDown Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-down"></i>
                    </div>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="up-vote-box" class="int vote-box up">
                        <span class="count">2</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbUp Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-up"></i>
                    </div>

                </div>
                <div class="text-container comments-truncate">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Consider this - none of the people who were living with Duncan while he was sick, and none of the people who treated Duncan on his first visit to the ER have developed the disease yet. Their watch period will end October 19, and with each day that passes without symptoms the odds that they will get Ebola get lower and lower.<br>
<br>
The worker who has contracted Ebola had interaction with Duncan when he was near death, when his viral load was highest. Any break in the protocol, especially of the way protective body coverings are removed, can cause an individual to be exposed. Everything about this worker's infection combined with the continued good health of those who had much more extensive contact with Duncan points toward a break in protocol as the source of exposure.
                    </p>
                    <div class="more-text-button">More</div>
                </div>
                <div class="action-container clearfix">
                    <span tabindex="0" class="reply int" role="button">

                <div class="text-container comments-truncate">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Everyone should understand what just happened.  CDC knew about the worker at least since Friday, but waited until Sunday at 3AM in an attempt to bury the news.  In fact, they could  have known about this case well before Friday.  The Liberian Ebola patient in Texas (Duncan) first sought treatment on September 25th, and the normal incubation period is 8 - 10 days, meaning they normally would have known about the worker between October 3 - 5th.  Instead, it's been 17 days since Duncan's first contact with the hospital, which means the incubation period would have been 17 days, which is very very uncommon.  21 days is the THEORETICAL outer limit, which is why it's the quarantine period.
                    </p>

    </li><li class="js-item comment  " data-page="19-181" data-cmt="1413127366621-e026374c-5083-43c3-b948-a51de3432341" data-uid="ZAPYM27Y2QYHD6PK7ZJSKURUUY" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1413139919383_2641">
        <div class="comment-container clearfix   " id="yui_3_16_0_1_1413139919383_2640">
        <div class="actions">
                    <button tabindex="0" class="comments-button-small flag Bxz-bb P-2" title="Report Abuse">
                        <i class="Icon C-w Fz-m"></i>
                    </button>
        </div>            <div class="img-container">
                <img src="http://l.yimg.com/dh/ap/social/profile/profile_b48.png" title="The Last Moderate" width="48" height="48">            </div>
            <div class="container" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1413139919383_2639">
                <div class="nickname">
                        <span tabindex="0" class="int profile-link" data-guid="ZAPYM27Y2QYHD6PK7ZJSKURUUY">The Last Moderate</span>
                    <span class="comment-timestamp">3 hours ago</span>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="down-vote-box" class="int vote-box down">
                        <span class="count">5</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbDown Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-down"></i>
                    </div>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="up-vote-box" class="int vote-box up">
                        <span class="count">13</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbUp Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-up"></i>
                    </div>

                </div>
                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1413139919383_2638">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Just for comparison purposes, over 30,000 people in the US die each year from the flu.  If you look at just the past 10 seasons, the average per year is 32,743.<br>
<br>
Or you can look at this way: In some years as few as 3,349 have died (way back in 1986-7).  But the highest annual average toll was 48,614, just seven seasons ago (2003-4).<br>
<br>
The reason for this wide variation: Deaths peak when the H3N2 strain of influenza A dominates. When it's H1N1 or influenza B, the toll is quite a bit lower.  Scientists can guess which strain may predominate in a given year, but it's only a guess. That's why the flu vaccine doesn't work in some years.  But it usually does.<br>
<br>
Just for perspective.
                    </p>
                    <div class="more-text-button">More</div>
                </div>

You have a 10.7 greater chance of winning the CA lottery than you do of catching/dying from Ebola.  Where is this perspective in the media?  Why the rush to push an epidemic panic?         <div class="comment-container clearfix   " id="yui_3_16_0_1_1413139919383_3785">
        <div class="actions">
                    <button tabindex="0" class="comments-button-small flag Bxz-bb P-2" title="Report Abuse">
                        <i class="Icon C-w Fz-m"></i>
                    </button>
        </div>            <div class="img-container">
                <img src="http://l.yimg.com/dh/ap/social/profile/profile_b48.png" title="KAY" width="48" height="48">            </div>
            <div class="container" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1413139919383_3784">
                <div class="nickname">
                        <span tabindex="0" class="int profile-link" data-guid="UR7NDCEQBQ6W6IGVYZZEA3XMIU">KAY</span>
                    <span class="comment-timestamp">7 minutes ago</span>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="down-vote-box" class="int vote-box down">
                        <span class="count">0</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbDown Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-down"></i>
                    </div>
                    <div tabindex="0" id="up-vote-box" class="int vote-box up">
                        <span class="count">0</span>
                        <i class="GSIcon IconThumbUp Fz-m Va-m comment-thumb-up"></i>
                    </div>

                </div>
                <div class="text-container comments-truncate" id="yui_3_16_0_1_1413139919383_3783">
                    <p class="comment-content">
                    As the average Joe nowadays rarely puts anything more into the job than they feel they absolutely have to, it always amazes me that management so often thinks an effective communication / education is to send out information in an email to be read or to be directed to a link.  Most folks trash the email without actually taking the time to read further, because they are already so busy and overwhelmed by their job tasks that they can't get out. <br>
<br>
As an example of this mentality, I used to work as a technical writer in a high tech company that programmed aerospace software.  When they'd upgrade internal software, the admin would send out an email with step-by-step instructions on how to do the upgrade.  Afterwards they would come around to check that the upgrade had been successfully achieved.  The head of the internal tech department told me that rarely did more than three people upgrade successfully -- and they were usually me, the secretary and the financial officer... because we knew we weren't computer experts, so actually followed the directions step-by-step.  On the other hand, the programmers, analysts, technical engineers, LAN administrators, QA testers, etc. usually failed the upgrade... because they were computer experts and thought they knew so much that they didn't need to waste time reading instructions.  Now, I'm suspecting that "expert" health care workers may be taking that same attitude when instructions are sent out on how to deal with Ebola...
                    </p>
                    <div class="more-text-button">More</div>
                </div>
                <div class="action-container clearfix">
                    <span tabindex="0" class="reply int" role="button">
                    Reply
                    </span>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>

                    <p class="comment-content">
                    Judge Jeanine is right! She says: <br>
Ebola - what a mess. No one - and I mean no one - should be allowed to enter the U.S. from any West African nation ravaged by Ebola.<br>
And any American citizen who goes there and wants to come home needs to be quarantined for 21 days until we figure out what we're doing.<br>
Look - we have a real problem. I don't want to hurt anybody. And I'm good with sending humanitarian aid to those in need.  Fill up those c130's with supplies and doctors and do military transports.<br>
But guess what?  At a certain point you take priority over everyone else in the world.  And when it comes to the health and security of your family - and my family - everyone else takes a back seat.<br>
The fact that we're even having this discussion is insane!<br>
Now we're told that it would be counterproductive to the economy of Liberia to stop flights from coming here.  Really? Another country's economy is not the criteria to determine whether we put our families at risk.<br>
And trying not to offend the rest of the world, making nice so people won't be angry or making other countries economically successful and any other politically correct hogwash coming out of Washington be damned!<br>
Your job is to protect us! Take a listen to President Obama:<br>
“First and foremost, I want the American people to know that our experts, here at the CDC and across our government, agree that the chances of an Ebola outbreak here in the United States are extremely low.” – September 16, 2014<br>
“The world is less violent than it has ever been. It is healthier than it has ever been.” – June 11, 2014<br>
Right, and you can keep your doctor and health care plan, Al Qaeda’s on the run and ISIS is not Islamic.

                    <p class="comment-content">
                    {...."This individual was following full CDC precautions, which are barrier and droplet so gown, glove, mask and shield," ....}<br>
<br>
Your precaution and protocol is fatally flawed.<br>
Protective gears (hazmat) becomes more infectious than the patient they tended wearing it. Bodily fluids on gloves and gown contaminate more easily than the ones on a patient.<br>
<br>
Nurses and doctors should go through chemical wash and rinse after each patient visit or contact. I've seen them taking of hazmat in locker room as if taking off a gown in normal hospital circumstance.<br>
<br>
Remember: hazmat is more infectious than the patient. It must be chemically disinfected and washed after each and every visit before they touch anything.<br>
<br>
<br>
CDC and most of the hospitals are utterly incompetent and I am certain ebola will be as wide spread as HIV once was.<br>

                    <p class="comment-content">
                    EBOLA : officially discovered in 1976.... nearly forty years later and still no official cure or vaccine!  Kill ratio of 60 to 90%, highly infectious through bodily fluids and can also survive outside a host body for a few days... thus contaminating the immediate environments as well.<br>
The natural reservoir for the virus was discovered only in 2005 ( in fruit bats) and two years ago the University of Manitoba was able to infect monkeys via airborne transmission of the virus from host pigs.  The more I learn about this, the more I realize that this plague has not been properly studied...WHAT ELSE DON'T WE KNOW ABOUT EBOLA?  It's past time our leaders admit that quarantine has failed and change tactics.... time to impose travel bans and monitor incoming flights!

If you want to protect yourself, just make sure your immune systems are purring...there are plenty of things out there to do that...if you know how to Google.  This may not be foolproof but like seat belts, it may lesson your chances of getting hurt or dying.
                    </p>
